title: This week in American history: Civil War begins in 1861, Lincoln assassinated in 1865.
body: This week marks the anniversary of two of the most important dates in U.S. history, the beginning of the Civil War in 1861 and the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln in 1865.On April 14, 1865 Lincoln was shot in Ford’s Theatre on 10th Street NW in Washington, D.C. He died the next morning in the Petersen House across the street.The National Park Service announced Tuesday that Ford’s Theatre and the Petersen House will remain closed, but NPS rangers will be stationed outside of both sites to talk with visitors from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Wednesday, April 14 and 7 a.m. to 4 p.m. on Thursday.The theatre and the Petersen House are preserved together as Ford's Theatre National Historic Site, administered by the National Park Service.On Friday, April 12, 1861, at 4:30 a.m., Confederate forces opened fire on the United States base at Fort Sumpter in South Carolina, beginning the American Civil War.Cut off from its supply lines and slow to respond to the rebel attack, the fort was surrendered and evacuated the next day.
